description:
For the first meet up of the group, I suggest a day hike in Gouvy (at the border with Luxembourg), 22 or 30 km.

Since I cannot read maps and can't use a compass, I will go for what is called a "marche fédérale". Those hikes are orgnaised by local hiking groups and in order to do the hike, you just pay 0.75 euros and follow the arrows.
This particular hike starts at 100 m from the Gouvy train stattion.

The train to go there takes 2h32 min.
Departure would be with the 8h02 train from Bruxelles-Central
Come back, depends on the lenght of the hike but if we do the 30 km, we would have to walk at more than 5 km/h to take the train at 16h26 (the train runs every 2h).

Anyone in ? Maybe one of the last summer weekends !
name: Day Hike in Gouvy - 30 or 22 km

description:
For those who (desperately) need to leave Brussels, even if the city will be car free that day, I propose the last stage of the GR564, backwards. The start will be in the Meuse valley, in the city of Huy. The warming will be the climbing of the side of valley (two times ;)) then the track goes into the countryside and it becomes progressively very flat. Some village crossings are in the program also.

Since pictures are better than words:
https://picasaweb.google.com/102282674505838562948/110412Gr564AvernasHuy

Some facts:
Distance: 32km, can be shortened to 20km or be made easier (the track goes along a bus line and a Ravel)
Kind of landscapes: ramble between houses and gardens in the first kilometres, hills and woods in the beginning, progressively evolving towards open fields and a landscape that matches the song "Le plat pays".

What you'll need with you:
The path is its biggest majority in concrete, asphalt or gravels, good walking shoes are sufficient. You will also need food and drink for the day, and clothes that are appropriate for the weather (almost no shadow at the end (if there's sun) and a lot of wind). About transportation:
- a train ticket from Brussels to Huy
- 2.90€ for the bus from Avernas to Landen (try to have the change, not sure the chauffeur will have enough coins if every one comes with bank notes)
- a train ticket from Landen to Brussels, better to buy it in advance since there's not so much time between the bus and the train.

Meet up at Bruxelles Luxembourg around 9.10. The train leaves at 9:23 and will arrive in Huy at 10.50. The goal is to catch the Huy-Landen bus, that is never far from the trail. Arrival in Brussels around 18.15.
name: GR564 (day hike, max 32km) - Huy-Avernas

description:
I propose the first stage of the GR573, which is considered to be one of the most various trails in Wallonia.

The first stage will start from Pepinster and  will follow the valley of the Vesdre, sometimes at the bottom of it, sometimes of the top of it. The journey will finish at Angleur  (a village inside the Liège agglomeration).

Since someone has already written a report about it, better to post a link: 
http://www.trekkings.be/gr573liegepepinster.htm 
It's in Dutch, but there are pictures.

Some facts: 
Total length: 28km (can be shortened if necessary) 
Kind of landscapes: mix of forests and fields, very hilly, urban at the end.

When and where: 
Meetup at Brussels North around 8.45. The hike will begin around 10.50 at the Pepinster train station. The duration is "undefined", but I expect to come back in Brussels around 20.30. If you have strong commitments in Brussels but want to take part, there are possibilities to come back earlier if necessary (train and busses).

Gear: 
Hiking shoes are necessary, only 20% of the trail is on regular roads. You will also need food and drink for the day, and clothes that are suited for the weather (that will be rainy).

Transport:

- a return train ticket to Pepinster


- 2.20€ for the bus (try to have the change)
name: GR573 - 1st stage (day hike, max 28km) - Liège Region

description:
Second stage proposed on the GR573: the fourth. The second will be programmed later, that being said. This stage begins at the second highest point of Belgium, the Baraque Michel. The first part will be the leaving of the National Park of the Hautes Fagnes, a peculiar landscape, then the trail will follow the valley of the Hoegne, also a place highly appreciated for its beauty. Then the trail will join a more classical countryside to the final destination: the city of Spa. 


As usual, the reports from others:
This one to the picture with the two arrows: http://www.trekkings.be/gr573montrigipolleur.htm
This one to Spa, backwards: http://www.trekkings.be/gr573spabelleheid.htm

Some facts:
Distance: 28km (estimated walking time: 7h)
Total ascent: 300m
Total descent: 720m

Kind of landscapes: "Hautes Fagnes", scenic valleys, countryside. The first 15 km are a loooong descent, then it becomes hilly.

Gear:
Waterproof hiking boots are necessary, and the necessary drinks, food and appropriate clothing to hold the day. Take also a headlamp, if you have one. It won't be necessary, but better to have it just in case.

Transportation:
Meetup at 7.50 in Brussels Central (early, I know. the excuse is: sunset around 19.00), the train leaves at 8.02. If we can hold a 4km/h pace and take a pause for lunch, arrival in Brussels around 21.00.
- a return train ticket to Verviers
- 2,90€ for the bus between Verviers and Mont-Rigi (try to have the change)
- one one-way train ticket Spa-Verviers, can be bought in Spa.
(better to use a Railpass if you have one)
name: GR573 - day hike, 28km - Baraque Michel-Spa

description:
We continue the GR573, but this time I won't try to give the number of the stage since it's completely mixed. The starting point will be the "Pont de Belleheid", that was (or will be) passed by in the previous (or next) stage The first part of the hike will be mostly in forests and the second in the countryside. The end will be the city of Pepinster. 

To have an overview:
http://www.trekkings.be/gr573montrigipolleur.htm (from the two arrows this time)
http://www.trekkings.be/gr573polleurspa.htm (to the first cross)

Some facts:
- Distance: 29km (expected walking time: 7h15)
- Total ascent: 850m
- Total descent: 950m

Gear:
Waterproof hiking boots are necessary, and the necessary drinks, food and appropriate clothing to hold the day. A good headlamp is also a must, it is possible that we will enjoy the sunset during the walk (which is a nicer way to say: it will probably be dark when we will finish the hike - sunset around 18.00 because of winter time).

Transportation:
Meetup at 7.50 in Brussels Central, the train leaves at 8.02. If we can hold a 4km/h pace and take a pause for lunch, arrival in Brussels around 21.00.
- a return train ticket to Verviers-Central (better to use a Railpass if you have one)
- 2,20€ for the bus between Verviers and Roquez (try to have the change)
name: GR573 - day hike, 29km - Belleheid-Pepinster

description:

name: Adeps Walk in Woluwé-Saint-Pierre (5, 10, 20 or 35km)

description:
[UPDATE] an additional train ticket is required (one-way Liège-Guillemins/Pepinster)

This activity was supposed to be the second stage of the GR573.

The starting point is Pepinster and the destination is Eupen, the capital of the German speaking part of Belgium. The first part will be in the outskirts of Verviers and then we will join Eupen by the country side, crossing some old villages. And of course, we will step in forests from time to time. 

Since someone has already written a report about it, better to post a link: 
http://www.trekkings.be/gr573pepinstereupen.htm 
It's in Dutch, but there are pictures.

Some facts: 
Total length: 28km 

Total ascent: 750m

Total descent: 600m

Gear: 

Waterproof hiking shoes are necessary, and the necessary drinks, food and appropriate clothing to hold the day. A good headlamp is also a must (little precision to someone who will recognise him/herself: a working headlamp with enough working and loaded batteries), if we make it to the end.

Transportation: 
Meetup at 7.50 in Brussels Central, the train leaves at 8.02. If we can hold a 4km/h pace and take a pause for lunch, arrival in Brussels around 21.00.

- a one-way ticket Liège-Guillemins/Pepinster

(better to use a Railpass if you have one)
name: GR573 - Day hike 28km - Pepinster-Eupen

description:
Due in a last minute change in my program, I propose an activity only 4 days in advance (to change from the last minute cancellations ;)). Quite different from the past activities: it's a loop and in another region. To make it easy: the starting point and arrival will be the city of Dinant, well known as touristic destination …but it's not the goal here ;) We will be heading North to the village called "Houx" to see another castle (because well, just for the principle, the Citadel of Dinant has to be avoided, but you have to see castles in that area…) and then will be heading to Leffe (just mentioned it because this name is known) and then come back to Dinant.

 

An overview, not from trekkings.be this time: http://fr.everytrail.com/view_trip.php?trip_id=1352261

 

Some facts

Level: intermediate

Length: 24km

Total ascent & Total descent: 670m

Kind of surfaces (by decreasing order): asphalt, earth/mud, gravel

Kind of landscape: first part: country side, second part: forests


Gear

Waterproof hiking shoes are necessary, and the necessary drinks, food and appropriate clothing to hold the day. The weather is expected to be rather cold (4-9°C), but dry. Even if Dinant is quite touristic, it won't be the case of other areas, so better to be autonomous. A good headlamp is also a must, if we make it to the end and/or are not too fast.

 

Transportation

Meetup at 9.10 in Brussels-Luxembourg, the train leaves at 9.23. Arrival in Brussels around 19.40, on a 4km/h basis and counting 1 hour of pause.

- a return train ticket to Dinant
name: Day hike 24 km, Dinant Region

description:
This activity will be the last one I propose for the GR573. We will start from the village of Sart-Lez-Spa, where we left in a previous walk (the second/fourth stage). We will be heading Spa, enter in a forest that offers some nice camera points on the city (so we won't cross it) and continue towards Pepinster. 


Of course, this descriptive wouldn't be complete without the descriptive of trekkings.be

http://www.trekkings.be/gr573spabelleheid.htm to the church

http://www.trekkings.be/gr573polleurspa.htm from Theux

Some facts

• Length: 28km (yep, again)

• Total ascent: ~700m

• Total descent: ~900m

• Surfaces (by decreasing order of importance): unsurfaced, asphalt, earth/mud, gravel

Gear

Waterproof hiking shoes are necessary, and the necessary drinks, food and appropriate clothing to hold the day. A good headlamp is also a must, if we make it to the end and/or are not too fast (for those of the last activities who were frustrated to not have used it: the days are getting shorter ;)).

Transportation

Meetup at 7.50 in Brussels Central, the train leaves at 8.02. Arrival in Brussels around 21.00, on a 4km/h basis and counting two long pauses.

- a return train ticket to Verviers-Central

- 2,2€ for the bus between Verviers and Sart-lez-Spa

(better to use a Railpass if you have one)
name: GR573 - day hike, 28km - Sart-lez-Spa/Pepinster

description:
I've seen that a FFMBP walk is organised in Brussels, if there are people who are interested, I post the link. The focus is mostly given to the important monuments of the city (European Community (won't feel like holiday for a big part of you, I guess ;)), city hall, St-Michel and Gudule Cathedral, Christmas market).

Here's my suggestion for the meeting point (at 15.00): the crossing between the Boulevard Lambermont and the Chaussée de Haecht, on the left side if you come from Montgomery. The closest tram stop is "Hopital Paul Brien" (Line 7, stops in Montgomery): http://goo.gl/maps/Rp7Ny

Athénée Fernand Blum - Avenue Ernest Renan, 12 - 1030 BRUXELLES


Folder:

http://www.ffbmp.be/WEBSITE/_Download/20131214BBW048.pdf

Like the Adeps walk, there's no strict timing, so if you want to start sooner or later (departures between 14.00 and 17.00), just write it in the comments.
name: FFBMP Ramble in Brussels - 12km or 16km

description:
For those who have an excess of calories due to the past weeks diet, here's a stage of the GR126. The starting point will be the city of Dinant and the trail will follow the valley of the river Lesse to the village of Houyet. You can find a report of the second half here: http://www.javaganu.net/wandelen/gr126/gr126_5.html in Dutch, but there are pictures). The first half is more "countrysidish", but there some nice spots too, like the rocks of Freyr.

Some facts

Difficulty: upper-intermediate

Distance: 32km

Walking time: 8 hours

Total elevation: ~850m

Kind of surfaces: unsurfaced (which means hardened mud with stones), mud, gravels, asphalt. With the combination of humidity and fallen leaves, it can be slippery.

Landscapes: Meuse and Lesse valleys, countryside, forests

Gear

Waterproof hiking shoes are necessary, and the necessary drinks, food and appropriate clothing to hold the day. A headlamp is necessary: the last 9km are in a forest (the one in the photos), with almost no access to roads as backup.

Transportation

- one return train ticket to Houyet (a Rail pass is better, or a shopping deal ticket: http://www.belgianrail.be/fr/titres-de-transport/billets/shopping-deal.aspx)

Schedule

Meetup at 8:10 at the Brussels-Luxembourg station. Arrival in Brussels around 19h40 if we walk fast, 21h40 otherwise.
name: GR126 - day hike, 32km

description:
Seeing the success of this Sunday Hike, I decided to have a look on the FFBMP & Adeps websites to avoid letting so many people on the touch. This one caught my eye. Partly in the city (for those who haven't seen it), partly in a surrounding forest and easily accessible.

The principle of these walks is quite simple: you arrive there, choose a circuit (4, 6, 10, 20 & 30), register at the secretariat (0.75€ for FFBMP) and follow the arrows. Don't hesitate to indicate your preferences in the comments.


The info about the walk is here:

http://www.ffbmp.be/WEBSITE/_Download/20140112NA029.pdf


There are trains leaving Brussels every hour (23min after the clock in Bruxelles Luxembourg). There are arrows from Namur station to the secretariat. Use the comments section to announce the circuit you want to follow and when you want to leave. I suggested 9.15 at Bruxelles-Luxembourg in the main hall, but feel free to do something else. (Note: the RailPass is less interesting than the week-end ticket for this kind of distance)
name: FFBMP Walk in Namur (4, 6, 12, 20 or 30km)

description:
Time for another stage of the GR126. Departure from Dinant, heading north this time, with Profondeville as final destination. The trail is dominated by forests with incursions in the countryside and villages.


Please note that the second half on this activity was on the GR126. http://www.meetup.com/brussels-hiking-group/events/153149222/


Some facts

Difficulty: upper-intermediate

Distance: 30km

Walking time: 8 hours

Total ascent: 1000m (with very steep hills)

Total descent: 970m

Kind of surfaces: earth/mud, unsurfaced, gravels, asphalt. With the combination of humidity and fallen leaves, it can be slippery.

Landscapes: forests, countryside

Waterproof hiking shoes are necessary, and the necessary drinks, food and appropriate clothing to hold the day. A headlamp is recommended, but optional.

Transportation

- one return train ticket to Dinant (or a Railpass, but the week-end ticket is a better deal in this case)

Schedule

Meetup at 8:10 at the Brussels-Luxembourg station. Arrival in Brussels around 19h00 if we walk fast.
name: GR126 - day hike 30km - Dinant/Profondeville

description:
After some time spent in the region of Dinant, back to the region of Liège. The starting point of this activity is the station of Angleur, the trail heads the south to cross the domain of the University of Liège and join the village of Esneux. It will then leaves the village (before really getting into it in fact), to join an arboretum, and then a forest. The last part of the trail will be in pastures/fields to join the final destination: the station of Rivage.

A guide from trekkings.be is available this time: http://www.trekkings.be/gr57angleurhamoir.htm (to the pictures in black and white, included)

Some facts

Difficulty: difficult (because of the weather - strong winds and rain showers)

Distance: 30km

Walking time: 7 hours

Total ascent: 900m

Total descent: 860m

Kind of surfaces: unsurfaced, earth/mud, asphalt

Landscapes: forests, countryside

Gear

Waterproof hiking shoes are necessary, and the necessary drinks, food and appropriate clothing to hold the day. A headlamp is recommended, but optional.

Transportation

- one return train ticket to Rivage (a RailPass is a better deal)

Schedule

Meetup at 7:50 at the Bruxelles-Central station. Arrival in Brussels around 19h00.
name: GR57 - day hike, 30km - Angleur/Rivage

name: Adeps Walk in Auderghem (5, 10, 15 or 20km)

description:
Logical continuation of the past GR activity: the next stage of the GR57. The trail follows the Ourthe valley, starting from the village of Barvaux. The first part will be mostly in the country side, joining the village of Durbuy and then Bomal. After Bomal, the trail will be mostly in forests and in "rocky" areas (the Belgian way: some significant rocks lost among trees), sometimes in the bottom of the valley, sometimes in the top of it. The final destination is the station of the village of Hamoir.


The guide for those who are interested: http://www.trekkings.be/gr57hamoirbarvaux.htm (it will be done in the other direction)

Some facts

Difficulty: upper intermediate

Distance: 27km

Walking time: 7 hours

Total ascent: 760m

Total descent: 820m

Kind of surfaces: unsurfaced, earth/mud, asphalt

Landscapes: forests, countryside, rocky areas

Gear

Transportation

- one return train ticket to Barvaux (a RailPass is a better deal — if you use the train often)

Schedule

Meetup at 8:40 at the Bruxelles-Luxembourg station. Arrival in Brussels around 21h00.
name: GR57 - day hike, 27km - Barvaux/Hamoir

description:
The author of one my favourite websites (trekkings.be) has awarded a very unexpected trail for its "Best Benelux Hiking Trail 2014": the Promenade Verte/Groene Wandeling that is entirely situated in the Region of Brussels-Capital. It would be then really a shame to not give it a try. This walk aims to be a loop around Brussels, but still remains inside it and stays has much as possible with parks or green areas.

A few links:

The official guide is to be found here (French/Dutch):

http://documentation.bruxellesenvironnement.be/documents/GW-PromenadeVerte.PDF?langtype=2060

The report of trekkings.be: http://www.trekkings.be/degroenewandeling.html

The map on everytrail.com: http://fr.everytrail.com/view_trip.php?trip_id=821490

(iPhone and Android app available)

The meeting point is 8.00 precise at the Boisfort train station. The loop will be done clockwise, and the upper bound is the whole loop (57km). Since this walk will be fast paced and aims to cover a big distance, it is reserved to trained walkers.

Given the trail is inside the region of Brussels, it often crosses bus, tram, train or metro lines. That gives a lot of flexibility to stop when you feel it (you can find more info about public transport in the guide).
name: Green Walk around Brussels - Day hike (30+km)

description:
Continuation of the covering of the Liège province by the GR trails (mostly because it is the most well deserved by public transportation, I have to admit it). The chosen trail this time is the GR15, from Spa to Aywaille (24km), and for those who fancy it, there will be an additional stage of the GR571 from Aywaille to Rivage (14km). The first part will be in the Spa country side, so mostly dominated by open pastures/fields. Then it will leave the fields to follow the valley of the Ninglinspo, one of the only rivers that matches the definition of "mountain stream" in Belgium (but at Belgian scale …and only after heavy rains). The trail will then join Aywaille, where the first part of the walk will stop. 

First part: http://www.trekkings.be/gr15spaaywaille.html

Second part: http://www.trekkings.be/gr571comblainninglinspo.htm

(the GR15 and GR571 run mostly one the same paths between Aywaille and Remouchamps)

Some facts

Difficulty: upper intermediate

First part

Distance: 24km

Total ascent: 750m, the elevation profile is the one of a "valley walk": flat areas between long hills.

Total descent: 850m

Kind of surfaces (by decreasing order of importance): unpaved roads, asphalt, earth/mud paths

Second part 

Distance: 14km

Total ascent: 400m

Total descent: 382m

Kind of surfaces: earth/mud, unsurfaced, asphalt

Please note that the pace will be adjusted to allow people doing the 38km to take the train at 19.00 in Rivage. So don't assume it will be an "relaxed" walk because it's shorter than the usual 30km I propose.

Gear

The usual waterproof hiking boots, appropriate clothing and food and drinks to hold the day.

Schedule

Meetup at 7.50 in Brussels-Central. Arrival in Brussels around 21h00 for those doing the 38km, 19.00 for those doing the 24km.

Transportation

One one-way train ticket Brussels->Spa, one one-way train ticket from Aywaille->Brussels (will work for the 24 and 38km). A rail pass is a better deal if you have one. Please note that start and end are not on the same train lines, so return trains tickets can't be used.
name: GR15/GR571 - day hike (24/38km) - Spa/Aywaille/Rivage

description:
Hello hiking enthusiasts!

Given the long waiting list (22 people) for the Spa-GR15-hike, I was surprised that nobody suggested a serial event on the same trail, BUT one hour later! So here it is! :) In this way, we do not interfere with the other group at all and can sleep 1 hour more!

There are trains to Spa every hour, and trains back from Aywaille every two hours... I propose to take the train at 9:02 (platform 1) from Brussels (arriving 11:10), and take the return train at 19:19 from Aywaille. We will keep a good pace but still have enough time to enjoy nature, take some lunch, and get some food/a drink at the end in the nice village of Aywaille before heading back. In the train we might meet the 38 km guys!

For more details on the trail, you can refer to the other meetup event. I would like to ask who wants to volunteer as "co-organizer", i.e. someone who meets the group at the Brussels station. I will jump on the train in Leuven. 

Any comments are welcome. See you on Sunday!
name: Spa-Aywaille (24 km)

description:
The best films from the 2013 Banff Mountain Film Festival are doing their world tour. Categories include mountain sport, mountain culture and mountain environment. They are often inspiring and sometimes amusing. More info on this year's programme can be found at www.banff.be.
Tickets cost about €16 online. All other performances in Brussels have sold out! I'm planning on going to this showing if anyone wants to come along. I've also got an extra ticket available.
name: Banff Mountain Film Festival World Tour

description:
Instead of the Ardennes, I propose to explore some terrain closer by this time. The green and undulating Hageland region of Vlaams Brabant!

When: 21 April (Easter)
Start: Brussel Central station at 9:14 (track 3) to Leuven, change trains in Leuven, at 10:05 (L2881) to Wezemaal. Arrival at 10:13. The station in Wezemaal is quite close to beginning of trail at the Wijngaardberg Natural reserve ("vineyard").
Trail: From Wezemaal we walk through forests to the Moedermeule (windmill), then we continue to the Castle of Horst, Kortrijk-Dutsel, Kessel-Lo and finish in Leuven. We (mostly) follow the Local GR Hageland.
Length: ~28 km.
Details: Unpaved/paved, mostly forests, with some hills and (short) climbs 

Highlights: Castle of Horst (Red Knight!), Natural Reserve Wijngaardberg, hills around Kessel-Lo, a beer/diner in Leuven. 

Expected net walking time: ~6 hours (we try to maintain 5 km/h while walking). 
Expected arrival in Leuven: ~17:30-18:00 (frequent 20 min trains to Brussels)

Let's celebrate Eastern together!

description:
A FFBMP (federation of belgian walking clubs) walk is organised in Huy on June, 6th. The principle of those walks is quite simple: you arrive there, choose a circuit, register at the secretariat (0.75€), follow the arrows and come back at the starting point. The available distances are 42, 30, 20, 13 and 8 km.

The only information is here: http://www.ffbmp.be/WEBSITE/_Download/20140705LG182.pdf

And because I don't have more information, the traditional "some facts" section will be limited to the distances.

 


From an organisational point of view, there are some differences with the GR activities: 

- no limited numbers of participants

- FFPMP are big scale events, there are checkpoints where you can buy drinks or something to eat, but it's of course recommended to take enough to drink and to eat.


- "subgroups" are formed according to the chosen loop and pace and are autonomous (the marking is good, there are a lot of people - especially on the small loops - so no risk to get lost), it's not the goal the group stays together. Everyone can walk closer to his/her ideal pace. 

So, don't hesitate to use the comment section to: 

• indicate your preferences for the distance

• propose another starting time if 8.15 doesn't suit you.

• to show that you've done more than just clicking "RSVP yes" in the invitation — the number of actual participants is usually much much lower than the number of "RSVP yes"...

My personal choice is to take the train at 8.23 at Bruxelles-Luxembourg and do the 42km loop at a "sporty" pace.

For the transportation, you need a return train ticket to Huy. There are trains every hour, the last train leaves Huy at 21.10 and arrives in Brussels in 22.40.

description:
Time flies... it's been one year since the hiking group has been created! No less than 30 day hikes have been organized covering an awe-inspiring 1000 km. In the sun, during rain, through bushes, over rocks, along rivers, visiting tiny villages, castles, old forests, passing by nosy cows, enjoying great views after tough climbs.

Hence, time to organize a special activity for the anniversary: 2 hikes starting from the same point, and finishing at the same place, but through different routes. Both will use the GR571, whose theme is the Ardens rivers. The two groups will walk together for about 8 km and then there will be a split. One group continues at the eastern side of the Amblève for a 32km walk following the Chefna river. The group on the western side will go for a 39km walk, mixing forests, pastures and fields, while following small streams. The trails will join near the big lakes around Coo. The idea is that the two groups will meet there again (if we synchronize well enough ;)) …or in the village of Coo. We will have a drink together to celebrate the first anniversary of the group.

The RSVP will only be open at 21.30 on Sunday, September, 7th. So you'll have the time to read the description and choose the right activity. Hopefully it will allow people not having a smartphone to join this one ;)


This activity is about the western side. This stage is in the more inhabited region, so it will offer a mix of forests (first half) and then country side (second half). There's a trekkings.be coverage:http://www.trekkings.be/gr571neufmoulinnonceveux.htm. The trail is organised on  a such way: it roughly follows the Amblève river, then when there's a significant stream going into it, the trail follows it upstream, then a second river is joined and is followed downstream ...until it is decided to join another one. That's how to add 7 km by following the same valley. Of course the goal is to arrive at the same time as the other group or before, and our biggest chance to achieve that is that they find some gold!

Difficulty: advanded

Distance: 39km

Expected walking time: around 8.00h (expected pace 5km/h)

description:
Time flies... it's been one year since the hiking group has been created! No less than 30 day hikes have been organized covering an awe-inspiring 1000 km. In the sun, during rain, through bushes, over rocks, along rivers, visiting tiny villages, castles, old forests, passing by nosy cows, enjoying great views after tough climbs.

Hence, time to organize a special activity for the anniversary: 2 hikes starting from the same point, and finishing at the same place, but through different routes. Both will use the GR571, whose theme is the Ardens rivers. The two groups will walk together for about 8 km and then there will be a split. One group continues at be at the eastern side of the Amblève for a 32km walk following the Chefna river. The group on the western side will go for a 39km walk, mixing forests, pastures and fields, while following small streams. The trails will join near the big lakes around Coo. The idea is that the two groups will meet there again (if we synchronize well enough ;)) …or in the village of Coo. We will have a drink together to celebrate the first anniversary of the group.

The RSVP will only be open at 21.30 on Sunday, September, 7th. So you'll have the time to read the description and choose the right activity. Hopefully it will allow people not having a smartphone to join this one ;)

This activity is heading EAST after the split. We first walk along the Ambleve river and then climb out of the valley along the small and wild Chefna river through the woods. Perhaps we find some gold among its rapids and tiny waterfalls. This is an awe-inspiring trail and involves the Mother-of-All-Belgium-Climbs: A whopping pants-dropp'n heart-stopp'n 400 meters non-stop! Then after the village Stoumont we head back to the Amblève valley and walk in the lush green. After having passed two large lakes, we end in Coo. Hopefully we can enjoy a nice drink there without being bothered by the ghastly Kabouter Plop.

description:
The weather forecast looks promising for Saturday, so I want to make a last minute suggestion for those who still do not have any plans and want to spend it outdoors.

There is a FFBMP (the French-speaking Federation of Popular Walking) walk organised in the municipality of Jette and its surroundings. The route will lead through the parks, woods, neighbourhoods of Jette, Ganshoren, Asse (Relegem, Kobbegem), Merchtem (Ossel) and the surface will be mainly asphalt and unsurfaced roads.

From the organisational point of view, FFPMP are big scale events, therefore, there is unlimited number of participants. Moreover, there might be some checkpoints or little shops/kiosks/supermarkets along the trail where you can buy drinks or food, but it is better to take something to drink and eat with you. 

Another good thing about this walk – independent of the chosen route, you will always be relatively close to Brussels city. So even if you choose, e.g. 22 km, and afterwards realise that it is too much, or you want to walk faster/slower than other people in your sub-group, you can always finish the walk on your own (there will be arrows/marking along the route) or finish the walk earlier and come back home (there should be an easy access to the public transportation).


The starting point is at Ecole Poelbos, Avenue du Laerbeek 110, 1090 JETTE and the only source of information is: http://www.ffbmp.be/WEBSITE/BEFR/07/Marches03.php

Please feel free to comment and indicate:
- your preference(s) for the distance;
- your preference(s) for the starting time (it can be at any time between 7.30 and 15.00, but please be aware that it is getting dark earlier).

Based on the chosen distance and starting time, we can form sub-groups and meet up to walk together. My personal choice is to walk 30 or 42 km. Also, I want to leave at 8.30 (latest 9.00) and target on average 5.5 km per hour. If you want to join me, please feel free to raise your hand! :)

description:
Let's escape the city and "think outside" the box on this free day! The theme of this hike in the Ardennes is the meandering Ourthe. The GR57 is certainly among the nicest trails in Belgium. Our trailhead is the trainstation in Tilff from where the path eventually climbs up to Roche-aux-Faucons (Falcon's rock). This scenic view is the #1 - and only ;) - attraction of Esneux according to tripadvisor (http://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g2437920-d3618720-Reviews-La_Roche_aux_Faucons-Esneux_Liege_Province_The_Ardennes_Wallonia.html). After a descend, and passing through a park with all kind of (exotic) trees, we climb out of the valley again through Bois de Esneux. In Comblain-au-Pont , we can get to the east side of the valley, walk towards Oneux and then descend to the station at Rivage (GR571) before sunset kicks in. Lots of forests on this hike, good mix of paved/unpaved paths and some nice views.

* Time: ~6h (aim: average of 5 km/h during walking)
* Level: Intermediate
* Total ascent: roughly 700 m
